titleInfo.subTitle: Miles Edward Richardson oral history interview, 2000-2006.

name.description: Miles Edward Richardson was born in Palestine, Tex., to Mark Carl and Florence Adams Richardson in 1932. He dropped out of high school in December 1949, a few months before he was due to graduate, and immediately joined the U.S. Air Force. Richardson stayed in the Air Force for four years, serving in the Korean War while he was stationed in Okinawa, Japan, for two years. After leaving the service, he slowly began taking college classes and eventually wound up at Stephen F. Austin State College, where he completed his B.S. in biology and history in 1957. That same year, he started the master's program in anthropology at Louisiana State University. After only one year there, Richardson transferred to the Ph.D. program at Tulane University. While a student at Tulane, he married a fellow student, Valerie Woodger. Richardson was able to go to Colombia on a medical grant and he did his dissertation fieldwork in San Pedro, Colombia, in 1962-63. For the next two years, while completing his Ph.D. at Tulane in the summers, he taught at Indiana State College (now Indiana University of Pennsylvania). Richardson earned his Ph.D. from Tulane in the spring of 1965 and started teaching at LSU that fall. He remained at LSU as a professor of anthropology for the next forty years. He was Departmental Chair (1970-72) and Acting Chair (1986-87). He held the Fred B. Kniffen Professorship and the Doris Z. Stone Professorship and served in numerous professional organizations including the Society for Humanistic Anthropology and the Southern Anthropological Society. Throughout his career, he conducted fieldwork in the southern U.S. and Latin America and authored several books and numerous scholarly articles, as well as several poems and short stories. Richardson died at the age of 79 on November 14, 2011.

mods.abstract: "Session I, which is transcribed, describes Richardson's early life in Palestine, Tex., between the 1930s and 1950s, including his father's work for the railroad, his mother's domestic duties, life on their farm, animals they kept, their garden, the use of well water and pumps, planting by the moon, folk remedies, the local lumber industry and ""sawmill kids,"" local pageants and events, his mother's death, his crisis of faith, and his first thoughts of becoming an anthropologist. He also discusses his service in the U.S. Air Force during the Korean War (1950-1954) and his ideas on evolution and anthropology.; Session II, which is indexed, describes his completing a bachelor's degree at Stephen F. Austin State College and starting the master's program at LSU (1957), including duties he had as part of his assistantship, classes and professors, his love of cultural geography, and anthropological theory of cultural evolution. He gives his recollections of LSU circa 1957-58, especially segregation and mandatory ROTC and civil rights activities. Richardson describes the doctoral program at Tulane (1958-1965), including work with Dr. Forrest La Violette on political activism of African-American ministers, fellow grad students including his wife Valerie, the popularity of folk music, and the difficulty in finding funding for research. He also discusses medical and dissertation research in Cali and San Pedro, Colombia in the early 1960s with accounts of life in the local communities and the difficulty of fieldwork.; Session III, which is indexed, gives Richardson's recollections of Cali, Colombia (1962 or 1963), his experiences while teaching at Indiana State College in Pennsylvania, his acknowledgment of the profound influence of Dr. La Violette, prominent theories in anthropology from the 1960s thru 1980s, the role of the Vietnam War and Civil Rights Movement on theories, and a discussion of his anthropological writing, fiction and poetry.; Session IV, which is indexed, discusses Richardson's first years teaching at LSU in the late 1960s, including reactions to the first African-American football players at LSU, campus protests on civil rights, the Vietnam War, the involvement of English Department faculty in the protests, the creation of Free Speech Alley, the reaction to the death of Martin Luther King Jr., Student Government President Ted Schirmer, and the cancellation of the homecoming queen crowning. He also discusses different reactions to New Archeology by Richardson and William Haag."
